snippet.title: Sam Mitchell announces AFL retirement to become West Coast Eagles assistant coach
snippet.content:
Four-time AFL premiership player and Brownlow Medallist Sam Mitchell has announced his retirement and is set to move into coaching at the West Coast Eagles next year. Mitchell - - will hang up his boots at the end of the season, having played 323 games so far over a 16-year career. He will see out the season on the field with West Coast before taking up an assistant coach position next year.
Mitchell, 34, , signing a one-year playing contract with a view to moving into a coaching role afterwards. It capped a decorated career at the Hawks, where the midfielder was drafted in 2001 and made his debut the following year before captaining the club to their first premiership in 17 years in 2008. Mitchell relinquished the captaincy at the end of the 2010 season but went on to help the club to a three-peat of flags in 2013, 2014 and 2015.
He won five Peter Crimmins Medals as Hawthorn's best and fairest player, the last of them coming in 2016 before he was traded. Mitchell also won All Australian honours in 2011, 2013 and 2015.
He has been one of the better players in his 16 games at West Coast this season, in a campaign where . Mitchell is the second Brownlow winner at the Eagles to announce he will hang up his boots after the season, with . A string of other West Coast veterans could follow, with speculation Drew Petrie, Mark LeCras and Sam Butler may be among them.
